posts.html:
What they are: Single-room occupancies (SROs) are a type of residential housing where occupants must share sanitary or food preparation facilities with the other units in the occupancy 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. They are designed as affordable housing options with specific characteristics:

Basic Requirements:

  • Single-room occupancies must include a minimum of four attached units that are independently rented and lockable 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Each unit must provide living and sleeping space for the exclusive use of an occupant 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Occupants must share sanitary or food preparation facilities with the other units in the occupancy. The developer may provide both facilities as shared facilities; however, when one of the facilities isn't shared, it must be provided in each unit for the exclusive use of the occupant 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Where They're Permitted

Single-room occupancies are permitted as follows: In the RL zone with a maximum of six units on each lot or parcel. In the RS, RM and RH zone with the maximum number of units consistent with the density standards of the corresponding zoning district 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Design Standards

Parking Requirements:

  • The parking maximum is one and one-half parking spaces per unit 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Bicycle Parking:

  • Six or fewer units: None. More than six units: One covered space per unit. Covered bicycle parking spaces may be located within a garage, storage shed, basement, utility room or similar area. In those instances in which the single-room occupancy has no garage or other easily accessible storage unit, the bicycle parking spaces may be sheltered under an eave, overhang, an independent structure, or similar cover 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Landscaping:

  • Single-room occupancies with more than six units must provide a minimum 15 percent landscaping 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Architectural Standards: For single room occupancies with more than six units, architectural standards are intended to provide detailed, human-scale design, while affording flexibility to use a variety of building styles for certain types of residential development 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code. These include requirements for building elevations, entrance orientation, and detailed design criteria.

Front Door Orientation: For single room occupancies, front door orientation standards are only required to be met for one entrance 2.1.1100 Other Design Standards | Bend Development Code, and the entrance must face the street, a common open space, or open onto a porch.

Review Process:

  • Six or Fewer Units: For minimum development standards review, compliance with approval criteria is required and will be verified through the building permit process. More Than Six Units: Site plan review is required 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Restrictions:

  • The use of a unit as a short-term rental is prohibited 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Single room occupancies represent an important affordable housing option in Bend, designed to provide individual living spaces while allowing shared facilities to keep costs down and promote efficient land use.

posts.html:
What they are: A single-unit detached dwelling means a single-unit dwelling on its own lot or parcel that does not share a wall with any other building D Definitions | Bend Development Code. This is the traditional standalone house that most people think of when considering residential housing.

Where They're Permitted

Single unit detached dwellings are permitted in all residential zones in Bend, including:

  • Urban Area Reserve (UAR)
  • Rural Residential (RL)
  • Standard Density Residential (RS)
  • Medium-10 Density Residential (RM-10)
  • Medium Density Residential (RM)
  • High Density Residential (RH)

Design Standards Summary

Setback Requirements

Front Setbacks:

  • RL and UAR Districts: The minimum front setback is 20 feet 2.1.300 Setbacks | Bend Development Code
  • RS, RM-10, RM, and RH Districts: The minimum front setback is 10 feet. Garages and carports with street access must be set back a minimum of 20 feet from the front property line 2.1.300 Setbacks | Bend Development Code

Side Setbacks:

  • RL and UAR Districts: The minimum side setback is 10 feet 2.1.300 Setbacks | Bend Development Code
  • RS, RM-10, RM and RH Districts: The minimum side setback is five feet 2.1.300 Setbacks | Bend Development Code

Rear Setbacks:

  • RL and UAR Districts: The minimum rear setback is 20 feet 2.1.300 Setbacks | Bend Development Code
  • RS, RM-10, RM and RH Districts 2.1.300 Setbacks | Bend Development Code have a minimum rear setback of 20 feet as well (though the specific number was cut off in the search results)

Building Height Limits

  • Buildings within the RS District may be no more than 30 feet in height 2.7.3950 Residential Zoning Districts | Bend Development Code
  • Buildings within the RM District may be no more than 45 feet in height, except single-unit homes may be no more than 35 feet in height 2.7.3950 Residential Zoning Districts | Bend Development Code
  • Buildings within the RH District may be no more than 55 feet in height 2.7.3950 Residential Zoning Districts | Bend Development Code

Garage and Carport Standards

  • Garages and/or carports must maintain a minimum front setback of 20 feet Bend CodeBend Code
  • Garages and/or carports that access an alley must have a driveway with a minimum length of 18 feet 2.7.3950 Residential Zoning Districts | Bend Development Code

Architectural Features

The following architectural features are allowed to encroach into the front, side and rear setbacks by no more than two feet provided a minimum setback of three feet is provided from the property line: eaves, chimneys including fireplace enclosures and chimney chases, bay windows up to eight feet in width, window wells, and similar architectural features 2.1.300 Setbacks | Bend Development Code.

Porch and Patio Standards

  • RL and UAR: An unenclosed covered or uncovered porch, patio, deck or stoop with a maximum floor height not exceeding 18 inches may be set back a minimum of 10 feet, as long as it does not encroach into a public utility easement 2.1.300 Setbacks | Bend Development Code
  • RS, RM, RM-10 and RH: An unenclosed covered or uncovered porch, patio, deck or stoop with a maximum floor height not exceeding 18 inches may be set back a minimum of six feet from the front property line, as long as it does not encroach into a public utility easement 2.1.300 Setbacks | Bend Development Code

Accessory Uses

An ADU may only be permitted on a lot or parcel with a single-unit detached dwelling, a townhome, or a manufactured home 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code, making single unit detached dwellings eligible for accessory dwelling units.

Review Process

For single unit detached dwellings, compliance with approval criteria is required and will be verified through the building permit process 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code, meaning they typically don't require separate land use review beyond standard building permits.

Single unit detached dwellings represent the most common and traditional form of residential development in Bend, with design standards that vary by zone but generally emphasize adequate separation between buildings, appropriate height limits, and streetscape compatibility.

What it is:An accessory dwelling unit (ADU) is a small dwelling unit on a property that contains a single-unit dwelling unit as the primary use. The ADU may be attached, detached, or within a portion of an existing dwelling unit. The maximum density standards do not apply to ADUs due to their small size and low occupancy. The standards of this section are intended to control the size, scale and number of ADUs on individual properties to promote compatibility with abutting land uses 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

From the definitions section: Accessory dwelling unit means a small, secondary dwelling unit on a lot or parcel with a single-unit dwelling as a primary use A Definitions | Bend Development Code.

Design Standards Summary

Where ADUs Are Permitted

An ADU may only be permitted on a lot or parcel with a single-unit detached dwelling, a townhome, or a manufactured home 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Important Exception: ADUs are not permitted on a lot or parcel created by a middle housing land division 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Number of ADUs

A maximum of one ADU is allowed per lot or parcel 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Size Requirements

Maximum Floor Area: The maximum floor area is 800 square feet 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Floor Area Definition: For purposes of measuring the ADU size in this subsection, "floor area" means the area measured in feet included inside the exterior surrounding walls of horizontal space intended to be a floored surface contained within the building or portion thereof, including slab-on-grade and exclusive of vent shafts and courts. When calculating floor area stairs are counted once unless the area under the stairs is part of the ADU floor plan, in which case the stairs are counted twice. Portions of the floor area with a sloped ceiling measuring less than five feet from the finished floor to the finished ceiling are not considered as contributing to the floor area 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Size Exception: Accessory structures attached to an ADU do not count towards the maximum floor area if they are not accessible from the interior of the ADU or if the accessory structure provides at least one allocated parking space for the ADU 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Parking Requirements

Parking: None 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This means ADUs are not required to provide any parking spaces.

Building Separation Standards

For Detached ADUs: A detached ADU must be a minimum of six feet apart from the primary single-unit dwelling as measured between their building footprints, unless exempted below 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Exemption: Does not apply when the primary single-unit dwelling was legally constructed prior to April 1, 2016, and the ADU is proposed to be located in a detached structure legally constructed prior to April 1, 2016, or within an existing footprint of an existing detached structure legally constructed prior to April 1, 2016 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Special Development Context Variations

In Small Dwelling Unit Developments: The maximum floor area for any dwelling unit is 800 square feet, except accessory dwelling units (ADUs) must not exceed 600 square feet. When two dwelling units are developed on site (i.e., a duplex or a single-unit detached dwelling with an ADU) the maximum total floor area permitted for all dwelling units is 1,200 square feet, cumulatively 3.8.300 Small Dwelling Unit Development | Bend Development Code.

In NorthWest Crossing Area: An accessory dwelling may be no larger than 40 percent of the living area, excluding the garage, of the primary dwelling, or 600 square feet, whichever is less. Maximum height for a detached accessory dwelling is 24 feet. Accessory dwelling units must meet the setbacks for the City of Bend Standard Density Residential (RS) Zone 2.7.310 Definitions | Bend Development Code.

Review Process and Infrastructure

ADUs are included in Minimum Development Standards Review for single-unit detached dwellings, townhomes, accessory dwelling units, duplexes, triplexes, quadplexes, single room occupancies with six or fewer units and cottage cluster developments 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code.

Infrastructure Exemptions:

  • Except for ADUs, street trees and planter strip landscaping are required in compliance with BDC 3.2.400, Street Trees and Planter Strip Landscaping, when there is an existing sidewalk or a sidewalk is required with the development 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code
  • Street and Alley Improvements for All Uses Other Than ADUs 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code indicates ADUs are exempt from certain street improvement requirements
  • Sidewalk Improvements for All Uses Other Than ADUs 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code indicates ADUs are also exempt from sidewalk improvement requirements

Short-Term Rental Restrictions

Applications submitted after November 4, 2021, located in the RL, RS, RM, RH, and MR outside of the Old Mill District boundary that include more than one dwelling unit on a property (e.g., ADUs, duplexes, triplexes, quadplexes, multi-unit, cottages, etc.) can only have one unit permitted as a short-term rental 3.6.500 Short-Term Rentals | Bend Development Code.

Other Restrictions

Not Permitted in Certain Development Types:

  • Accessory dwelling units are not permitted in cottage cluster developments 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code

Home Business Use: No more than 25 percent of the dwelling unit, including the floor area of garages, accessory structures and an ADU, may be utilized for all home business uses 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

ADUs represent an important affordable housing tool in Bend, designed to increase housing supply while maintaining neighborhood character through size limitations and compatibility standards. They offer significant flexibility in terms of infrastructure requirements while being subject to careful size and placement controls.

What it is: Manufactured homes and prefabricated structures are permitted on individual lots, subject to building permit compliance with the following design standards 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. These are factory-built housing units that are placed on individual residential lots, similar to traditional single-unit detached dwellings, but built off-site and transported to the property.

Design Standards Summary

Applicability of Standards

The following standards do not apply to units that existed on lots within the City prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this code 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This means these standards only apply to new manufactured homes and prefabricated structures, not those that were already in place when the current code was adopted.

Key Design Standards

1. Thermal Envelope Requirements The manufactured home or prefabricated structure must be certified by the manufacturer to have an exterior thermal envelope meeting performance standards which reduce levels equivalent to the performance standards required of single-unit dwellings constructed under the Low-Rise Residential Dwelling Code 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

This means manufactured homes and prefabricated structures must meet the same energy efficiency standards as site-built homes, ensuring they provide equivalent insulation and thermal performance.

2. Historic District Restrictions The manufactured home or prefabricated structure must not be located in a designated historic district 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

This restriction preserves the historic character of designated areas by preventing the placement of manufactured homes that might not match the architectural style or materials of historic buildings.

ADU Compatibility

Manufactured homes on individual lots are eligible for accessory dwelling units: An ADU may only be permitted on a lot or parcel with a single-unit detached dwelling, a townhome, or a manufactured home 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Related Development Types

The code also addresses two other forms of manufactured housing development:

Manufactured Home Subdivisions:

  • Manufactured home subdivisions are reviewed as a Type II application for tentative plan approval 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • The minimum lot area and dimensions within a manufactured home subdivision are the same as that allowed within the underlying zone 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Manufactured home subdivisions may contain manufactured homes, prefabricated structures and related accessory structures 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Setbacks are the same as provided in the underlying zone 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Manufactured Home Parks:

  • Manufactured home parks are reviewed as a Type II application for site plan review 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • All manufactured home parks must be a minimum area of one acre 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • The maximum number of manufactured homes allowed within a manufactured home park must not exceed 10 units per acre 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Review Process

Since manufactured homes and prefabricated structures on individual lots are subject to "building permit compliance," they typically follow the same review process as other single-unit detached dwellings, which means they generally only require building permits rather than separate land use reviews.

Underlying Zone Standards

Manufactured homes and prefabricated structures on individual lots must comply with all the standard requirements of the underlying residential zone, including:

  • Setback requirements
  • Building height limits
  • Lot coverage standards
  • Density requirements
  • All other applicable zoning district standards

Summary

Manufactured homes and prefabricated structures on individual lots represent an affordable housing option in Bend that must meet the same thermal performance standards as site-built homes while being restricted from historic districts. They are treated similarly to traditional single-unit detached dwellings in terms of zoning compliance and are eligible for accessory dwelling units. The primary design standards focus on ensuring energy efficiency equivalent to conventional construction and preserving historic district character, while allowing these housing types to function within standard residential development patterns.

What is a Manufactured Home Park?

Manufactured home parks are reviewed as a Type II application for site plan review in conformance with ORS Chapter 446, the provisions of this title and the following criteria 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. A manufactured home park is a development where multiple manufactured homes are placed on a single property with shared infrastructure and common facilities, rather than on individual lots.

Design Standards Summary

Review Process

Manufactured home parks are reviewed as a Type II application for site plan review 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code, which means they require a more comprehensive review process than simple building permits, including public notice and review by planning staff.

Minimum Area Requirements

All manufactured home parks must be a minimum area of one acre 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This ensures sufficient space for multiple units and necessary infrastructure.

Density Standards

The maximum number of manufactured homes allowed within a manufactured home park must not exceed 10 units per acre. The average area of a mobile home site must not be less than 4,000 square feet excluding roadway, recreation areas and other accessory facilities. No manufactured home site must be less than 2,000 square feet in area 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Access Requirements

Manufactured home park accesses must be located on public streets improved to a minimum width of 36 feet and which are improved to a point intersecting a collector or arterial street 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This ensures adequate access for emergency vehicles and residents.

Permitted Uses Within Parks

Manufactured home parks may contain manufactured homes, prefabricated structures and accessory structures permitted in this chapter, community laundry and recreation facilities and other common buildings for use by park residents only, and one residence other than a manufactured home for the use of a caretaker or a manager responsible for maintaining or operating the property 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Internal Infrastructure Standards

Park Streets: The minimum surfaced width of the roadway within an access way must be 24 feet if there is no parking allowed and 30 feet if parking is allowed on both sides. The first 50 feet of the access way measured from the public street must be surfaced to a minimum width of 30 feet and must be connected to the existing public street according to plans approved by the City 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Improvement Standards: The improvement of driveways, walkways, streets, drainage and other utilities must conform to adopted State standards for such or conform to the City's Standards and Specifications manual, whichever is more restrictive 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Special Density Incentives for Redevelopment

Enhanced Density Opportunities: The Oregon State law allows manufactured home parks to develop at a maximum residential density of 10 units per acre regardless of the underlying zone. This overlay will provide special increased density incentives for existing parks that are redeveloped 2.7.920 Residential Density | Bend Development Code.

Manufactured home parks in existence at the date of adoption of this overlay with an occupancy rate of at least 80 percent, that are developed in accordance with the City Ordinance NS-2036 and the provisions of the City of Bend Development Code, shall be allowed to develop at a residential density 2.7.920 Residential Density | Bend Development Code higher than the standard 10 units per acre.

Additional Density Bonus: Where an existing manufactured home park already has a Bend Comprehensive Plan Density of Urban Residential Medium Density at the date of adoption of this overlay, the density bonus may be increased to RH, Urban High Density Residential District with the same provisions for redevelopment as described above 2.7.920 Residential Density | Bend Development Code.

Redevelopment Provisions

The code includes extensive provisions for manufactured home park redevelopment, including:

Transition Standards: Where a redeveloping manufactured home park adjoins a Residential Zone, the development along the perimeter of the site within 100 feet of the property boundary shall be subject to the development standards of the adjoining Residential Zone including but not limited to lot coverage, building heights and setbacks 2.7.930 Special Development Standards | Bend Development Code.

Building Height Bonuses: To encourage innovative housing designs, provide more efficient use of land, encourage the preservation of open space and existing trees and to achieve greater allowable densities, an increase in building height not to exceed 10 feet above the height of the zone may be allowed provided the applicant's proposal meets all of the following criteria: The added height will provide for additional affordable housing units. The additional building height is needed to preserve more than 20 percent of the priority trees or more than 25 percent of the total DBH of regulated trees 2.7.930 Special Development Standards | Bend Development Code.

Tenant Protection Requirements

Bend has extensive tenant protection measures for manufactured home park closures, including requirements for:

  • No person may close a manufactured home park unless a manufactured home park closure permit has been obtained 7.45.015 Manufactured Home Park Closure Permit | Bend Code
  • Payment plans for relocated tenants
  • Housing assistance for displaced residents
  • Affordable housing density bonuses tied to tenant assistance

Summary

Manufactured home parks in Bend are regulated as comprehensive developments that must meet specific infrastructure, density, and access standards while providing community facilities for residents. They offer an important affordable housing option with the potential for redevelopment at higher densities, particularly when combined with affordable housing commitments and tenant protection measures. The design standards ensure adequate space per unit, proper infrastructure, and compatibility with surrounding neighborhoods while allowing flexibility for innovative redevelopment approaches.

posts.html:
What it is: Single-unit attached housing (townhome units on individual lots) must comply with the standards in subsections (D)(1) through (D)(5) of this section 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

More specifically: For purpose of this section, a "townhome" means a dwelling unit, located on its own lot, sharing one or more common walls with one or more dwelling units. As shown in Figure 3.6.200.D.1 the common wall must be fully enclosed and shared for at least 25 percent of the length of each dwelling unit's enclosed elevation, not including uncovered or open, covered porches, patios, decks or stoops 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

The common wall may be any wall of the dwelling unit, including the wall of an attached garage. As shown on Figure 3.6.200.D.2, townhomes may have detached garages or ADUs that share a common wall between the two lots or parcels 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Design Standards Summary

Building Mass and Configuration

The number and width of consecutively attached townhome units are not restricted 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This means there's no limit on how many townhomes can be attached together in a row.

Access Requirements

Alley Access: For lots or parcels abutting an alley, access must be taken from the alley in accordance with BDC 3.1.400(F)(3) 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Street Access Standards: Where there is no abutting alley, townhomes receiving access directly from a street must comply with the following standards, in order to minimize interruption of adjacent sidewalks or multi-use paths by driveway entrances, slow traffic, improve appearance of the streets, and minimize paved surfaces for better stormwater management 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code:

  • Townhomes may have a maximum of one driveway approach and must comply with the following: Townhomes with frontages on streets of different classifications must access the street with the lowest classification 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • The total width of shared driveway approaches must not exceed 32 feet. When a driveway serves more than one lot, the developer must record an access and maintenance easement/agreement to benefit each lot, prior to building permit issuance 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Driveway approaches on local streets may be separated in compliance with the following: (A) Approaches must be separated by a minimum of seven feet; (B) Approaches must not exceed 16 feet in width 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Driveway Width: The minimum driveway width must be 10 feet 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Architectural Design Standards

Garage Door Standards: The maximum combined garage door width facing the street is 50 percent of the total building width. The maximum combined garage door width facing the street may be up to 60 percent of the total building width if the front door entrance is within 10 feet of the longest street-facing wall of the dwelling unit 2.1.950 Design Standards (Triplex, Quadplex, Townhome, and Single-Room Occupancy) | Bend Development Code.

Front Door Orientation: For townhome units, this standard only applies to the interior units 2.1.1100 Other Design Standards | Bend Development Code (referring to front door orientation requirements).

Window and Door Requirements: A minimum of 15 percent of the area of all street facing facades must include windows and/or doors 2.1.950 Design Standards (Triplex, Quadplex, Townhome, and Single-Room Occupancy) | Bend Development Code.

Common Area Management

Common areas must be maintained by a homeowners association or other legal entity. A homeowners association may also be responsible for exterior building maintenance. A copy of any applicable covenants, restrictions and conditions must be recorded and provided to the City prior to issuance of a building permit 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Review Process

Townhomes are included in Minimum Development Standards Review for Single-Unit Detached Dwellings, Townhomes, Accessory Dwelling Units, Duplexes, Triplexes, Quadplexes, Single Room Occupancies with Six or Fewer Units and Cottage Cluster Developments 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code.

ADU Compatibility

An ADU may only be permitted on a lot or parcel with a single-unit detached dwelling, a townhome, or a manufactured home 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This means townhomes are eligible for accessory dwelling units.

Parking Standards

This section does not apply to single-unit detached, accessory dwelling units, manufactured dwellings, duplexes, triplexes, quadplexes, townhomes, live/work townhomes and cottage developments 3.3.300 Vehicle Parking Standards for On-Site Parking | Bend Development Code - referring to maximum parking limitations, meaning townhomes are generally exempt from parking maximums.

Special Variations in Different Zones

In Specific Master Planned Areas: Townhomes must comply with the following standards, which replace the standards in BDC 3.6.200(D): Building Mass/Setbacks. The number and width of single-unit consecutively attached townhomes on individual lots is not restricted. Frontage and Access. Individual lots for townhome developments need not have frontage on a public or private street if the lots front on common area and alley access is provided to each unit 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code.

Live/Work Townhomes: The commercial portion of the building must not exceed 50 percent of the floor area, excluding any garage 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code.

Urban Dwelling Sites

Townhomes, duplexes, triplexes, quadplexes and multi-unit 3.8.800 Urban Dwelling Sites | Bend Development Code are permitted uses in Urban Dwelling Sites, with special design standards that replace the design standards of the underlying zoning district and all the standards in BDC 3.6.200(D), Townhomes 3.8.800 Urban Dwelling Sites | Bend Development Code.

Summary

Townhomes in Bend are single-unit attached dwellings on individual lots that share common walls with adjacent units. They offer a middle-density housing option with specific design standards focused on managing street access, ensuring adequate architectural detail, and maintaining neighborhood compatibility. Key features include requirements for shared wall connections, coordinated access management, homeowners association governance, and flexibility in building mass while maintaining street-oriented design standards. Townhomes are eligible for ADUs and can be developed in various configurations depending on the specific zone and development context.

posts.html:
What it is: A duplex means two dwelling units on one lot or parcel. For permitting purposes, units may be attached vertically or horizontally or detached D Definitions | Bend Development Code. This means a duplex can be configured in several ways - side-by-side (horizontal), stacked (vertical), or as two separate buildings on one property.

Design Standards Summary

Building Separation Standards

Detached dwelling units must be a minimum of six feet apart as measured between their building footprints 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This applies when the duplex consists of two separate buildings rather than attached units.

Access and Driveway Standards

Alley Access Priority: For lots or parcels abutting an alley, access must be taken from the alley in accordance with BDC 3.1.400(F)(3) 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Street Access Standards: When there's no alley, duplexes may have a maximum of two driveway approaches 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code and must comply with the following:

  • The total width of all driveway approaches must not exceed 32 feet per frontage 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Driveway approaches may be separated when located on a local street. If approaches are separated, they must be separated by a minimum of seven feet 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code

Multiple Frontage Standards: In addition, lots or parcels with more than one frontage must comply with the following: Lots or parcels must access the street with the lowest classification. Lots or parcels with frontages only on collectors and/or arterial streets may have one driveway approach 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code.

Specific Access Configurations: For lots with frontages only on local streets: Duplexes may have two driveway approaches not exceeding 32 feet in total width on one frontage or one maximum 16-foot-wide driveway approach per frontage 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Clear Vision Requirements

Clear vision standards do not apply between driveway approaches for duplexes, triplexes and quadplexes on local streets. All other standards in BDC 3.1.500, Clear Vision Areas, apply 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Minimum Driveway Width

The minimum driveway width must be 10 feet 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Architectural Design Standards

Multi-Unit Standards Apply: This section applies to all of the following types of buildings: Multi-unit residential 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code, which includes duplexes. These standards require:

  • All building elevations must provide doors, porches, balconies, terraces and/or windows for a minimum of 30 percent of each full and partial building story. A minimum of 40 percent is required for street-facing elevations located within 50 feet of a front lot line 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code
  • A minimum of one building must have an entrance facing the street or be oriented to a side yard when a direct pedestrian walkway is provided between the building entrance and the street 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code

Review Process

Duplexes are included in Minimum Development Standards Review for Single-Unit Detached Dwellings, Townhomes, Accessory Dwelling Units, Duplexes, Triplexes, Quadplexes, Single Room Occupancies with Six or Fewer Units and Cottage Cluster Developments 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code.

Front Door Orientation Standards

For duplexes, triplexes and quadplexes, this standard is only required to be met for one of the dwelling units 2.1.1100 Other Design Standards | Bend Development Code (referring to front door orientation requirements).

Pedestrian Access Requirements

A hard surface pedestrian access route, a minimum width of four feet, must be provided from each dwelling unit to the street upon which it is addressed. If the route is fenced, there must be a gate to allow access 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code.

Conversion Allowances

Conversion of an existing single-unit detached dwelling or duplex to a triplex or quadplex is allowed; provided, that the conversion does not increase nonconformance 2.1.200 Permitted and Conditional Uses | Bend Development Code.

Special Context Applications

Urban Dwelling Sites: Accessory dwelling units, townhomes, duplexes, triplexes, quadplexes and multi-unit 3.8.800 Urban Dwelling Sites | Bend Development Code are permitted in Urban Dwelling Sites with special design standards that replace the design standards of the underlying zoning district and all the standards in BDC 3.6.200(D), Townhomes, 3.6.200(H), Duplex, Triplex and Quadplex Development 3.8.800 Urban Dwelling Sites | Bend Development Code.

Small Dwelling Unit Development: In the Small Dwelling Unit Development category, When two dwelling units are developed on site (i.e., a duplex or a single-unit detached dwelling with an ADU) the maximum total floor area permitted for all dwelling units is 1,200 square feet, cumulatively 3.8.300 Small Dwelling Unit Development | Bend Development Code.

Transition Standards for Larger Developments

When multi-unit buildings containing five or more units, single-room occupancies with more than six units or nonresidential uses abut a detached single-unit dwelling or duplex on land designated RS, any side or rear setback abutting the RS land must increase one-half foot for each foot by which the building height exceeds 20 feet 2.7.3950 Residential Zoning Districts | Bend Development Code. This shows that duplexes are recognized as needing protection from larger-scale development.

Master Plan Integration

Several master planned developments specifically mention duplexes: The Petrosa Master Planned Development implements the BCP by ensuring capacity for a minimum of 1,100 housing units within the Northeast Edge Expansion Area and including at least 110 single-unit attached housing units and at least 440 multi-unit and duplex/triplex housing units 2.7.3950 Residential Zoning Districts | Bend Development Code.

Summary

Duplexes in Bend are two-unit residential developments that can be configured as attached or detached units on a single lot. The design standards focus on managing vehicular access through limited driveway approaches, ensuring adequate building separation when detached, maintaining pedestrian connectivity, and providing architectural detail that creates human-scale design. Duplexes are treated as a middle-density housing type that bridges single-unit and multi-unit development, with standards that emphasize compatibility with surrounding neighborhoods while allowing efficient use of land. They follow a streamlined review process and are eligible for various development alternatives and special district applications.

What it is: A triplex is a residential building containing three dwelling units on one lot or parcel. While the code doesn't provide a specific definition of "triplex" in the definitions section, it's consistently referenced throughout as part of the "duplex, triplex and quadplex development" category, indicating it's a three-unit residential building.

Design Standards Summary

Building Separation Standards

Detached dwelling units must be a minimum of six feet apart as measured between their building footprints 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This applies when the triplex consists of separate buildings rather than attached units.

Access and Driveway Standards

Alley Access Priority: For lots or parcels abutting an alley, access must be taken from the alley in accordance with BDC 3.1.400(F)(3) 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Street Access Standards: When there's no alley, triplexes may have a maximum of three driveway approaches 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code and must comply with the following:

  • The total width of all driveway approaches must not exceed 32 feet per frontage 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Driveway approaches may be separated when located on a local street. If approaches are separated, they must be separated by a minimum of seven feet 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code

Multiple Frontage Standards: In addition, lots or parcels with more than one frontage must comply with the following: Lots or parcels must access the street with the lowest classification. Lots or parcels with frontages only on collectors and/or arterial streets may have one driveway approach 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code.

Specific Access Configurations: For lots with frontages only on local streets: Triplexes may have three driveway approaches not exceeding 32 feet in total width on one frontage or two driveway approaches not exceeding 32 feet in total width on one frontage and one maximum 16-foot-wide driveway approach on one other frontage 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Clear Vision Requirements

Clear vision standards do not apply between driveway approaches for duplexes, triplexes and quadplexes on local streets. All other standards in BDC 3.1.500, Clear Vision Areas, apply 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Minimum Driveway Width

The minimum driveway width must be 10 feet 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Architectural Design Standards

Specific Triplex Standards Apply: This section's architectural design standards apply to all of the following types of buildings: Triplex 2.1.950 Design Standards (Triplex, Quadplex, Townhome, and Single-Room Occupancy) | Bend Development Code. These standards include:

Garage Door Standards: The maximum combined garage door width facing the street is 50 percent of the total building width. The maximum combined garage door width facing the street may be up to 60 percent of the total building width if the front door entrance is within 10 feet of the longest street-facing wall of the dwelling unit 2.1.950 Design Standards (Triplex, Quadplex, Townhome, and Single-Room Occupancy) | Bend Development Code.

Window and Door Requirements: A minimum of 15 percent of the area of all street facing facades must include windows and/or doors 2.1.950 Design Standards (Triplex, Quadplex, Townhome, and Single-Room Occupancy) | Bend Development Code.

Multi-Unit Standards Also Apply: This section applies to all of the following types of buildings: Multi-unit residential 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code, which includes triplexes. These standards require:

  • All building elevations must provide doors, porches, balconies, terraces and/or windows for a minimum of 30 percent of each full and partial building story. A minimum of 40 percent is required for street-facing elevations located within 50 feet of a front lot line 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code
  • A minimum of one building must have an entrance facing the street or be oriented to a side yard when a direct pedestrian walkway is provided between the building entrance and the street 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code

Front Door Orientation Standards

For duplexes, triplexes and quadplexes, this standard is only required to be met for one of the dwelling units 2.1.1100 Other Design Standards | Bend Development Code (referring to front door orientation requirements).

Review Process

Triplexes are included in Minimum Development Standards Review for Single-Unit Detached Dwellings, Townhomes, Accessory Dwelling Units, Duplexes, Triplexes, Quadplexes, Single Room Occupancies with Six or Fewer Units and Cottage Cluster Developments 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code.

Pedestrian Access Requirements

A hard surface pedestrian access route, a minimum width of four feet, must be provided from each dwelling unit to the street upon which it is addressed. If the route is fenced, there must be a gate to allow access 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code.

Conversion Allowances

Conversion of an existing single-unit detached dwelling or duplex to a triplex or quadplex is allowed; provided, that the conversion does not increase nonconformance 2.1.200 Permitted and Conditional Uses | Bend Development Code.

Special Context Applications

Urban Dwelling Sites: Accessory dwelling units, townhomes, duplexes, triplexes, quadplexes and multi-unit 3.8.800 Urban Dwelling Sites | Bend Development Code are permitted in Urban Dwelling Sites with special design standards that replace the design standards of the underlying zoning district and all the standards in BDC 3.6.200(D), Townhomes, 3.6.200(H), Duplex, Triplex and Quadplex Development 3.8.800 Urban Dwelling Sites | Bend Development Code.

Master Plan Integration

Several master planned developments specifically mention triplexes: The Stevens Ranch Master Planned Development implements the BCP residential density policy for DSL/Stevens Ranch by ensuring the capacity for at least 1,000 dwelling units within the Master Plan boundary, including at least 11 percent single-unit attached housing and at least 41 percent multi-unit and duplex/triplex/quadplex housing types 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code.

Alley Access Requirements in Some Areas

For lots or parcels abutting an alley, access may be required to be taken from the alley in accordance with BDC 3.1.400(F)(3) 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code in certain master planned areas.

Engineering Standards

In certain contexts: When lots or parcels only have frontages on collector streets or only on arterial streets, the City Engineer will determine which frontage may have one driveway approach based on the following: Distance from the nearest intersection; Clear vision areas; Topography; Utility conflicts; and Pedestrian and bike conflicts in the vicinity 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code.

Summary

Triplexes in Bend are three-unit residential developments that can be configured as attached or detached units on a single lot. The design standards focus on managing vehicular access through controlled driveway approaches (up to three), ensuring adequate building separation when detached, maintaining pedestrian connectivity, and providing architectural detail including specific garage door width limitations and window/door area requirements. Triplexes are treated as a middle-density housing type that bridges duplex and larger multi-unit development, with standards that emphasize compatibility with surrounding neighborhoods while allowing for efficient use of land. They follow a streamlined review process and are eligible for various development alternatives and special district applications, making them an important component of Bend's housing diversity strategy.

 * All building elevations must provide doors, porches, balconies, terraces and/or windows for a minimum of 30 percent of each full and partial building story. A minimum of 40 percent is required for street-facing elevations located within 50 feet of a front lot line 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code
 * A minimum of one building must have an entrance facing the street or be oriented to a side yard when a direct pedestrian walkway is provided between the building entrance and the street 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code


Front Door Orientation Standards

For duplexes, triplexes and quadplexes, this standard is only required to be met for one of the dwelling units 2.1.1100 Other Design Standards | Bend Development Code (referring to front door orientation requirements).


Review Process

Triplexes are included in Minimum Development Standards Review for Single-Unit Detached Dwellings, Townhomes, Accessory Dwelling Units, Duplexes, Triplexes, Quadplexes, Single Room Occupancies with Six or Fewer Units and Cottage Cluster Developments 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code.


Pedestrian Access Requirements

A hard surface pedestrian access route, a minimum width of four feet, must be provided from each dwelling unit to the street upon which it is addressed. If the route is fenced, there must be a gate to allow access 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code.


Conversion Allowances

Conversion of an existing single-unit detached dwelling or duplex to a triplex or quadplex is allowed; provided, that the conversion does not increase nonconformance 2.1.200 Permitted and Conditional Uses | Bend Development Code.


Special Context Applications

Urban Dwelling Sites: Accessory dwelling units, townhomes, duplexes, triplexes, quadplexes and multi-unit 3.8.800 Urban Dwelling Sites | Bend Development Code are permitted in Urban Dwelling Sites with special design standards that replace the design standards of the underlying zoning district and all the standards in BDC 3.6.200(D), Townhomes, 3.6.200(H), Duplex, Triplex and Quadplex Development 3.8.800 Urban Dwelling Sites | Bend Development Code.


Master Plan Integration

Several master planned developments specifically mention triplexes: The Stevens Ranch Master Planned Development implements the BCP residential density policy for DSL/Stevens Ranch by ensuring the capacity for at least 1,000 dwelling units within the Master Plan boundary, including at least 11 percent single-unit attached housing and at least 41 percent multi-unit and duplex/triplex/quadplex housing types 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code.


Alley Access Requirements in Some Areas

For lots or parcels abutting an alley, access may be required to be taken from the alley in accordance with BDC 3.1.400(F)(3) 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code in certain master planned areas.


Engineering Standards

In certain contexts: When lots or parcels only have frontages on collector streets or only on arterial streets, the City Engineer will determine which frontage may have one driveway approach based on the following: Distance from the nearest intersection; Clear vision areas; Topography; Utility conflicts; and Pedestrian and bike conflicts in the vicinity 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code.


Summary

Triplexes in Bend are three-unit residential developments that can be configured as attached or detached units on a single lot. The design standards focus on managing vehicular access through controlled driveway approaches (up to three), ensuring adequate building separation when detached, maintaining pedestrian connectivity, and providing architectural detail including specific garage door width limitations and window/door area requirements. Triplexes are treated as a middle-density housing type that bridges duplex and larger multi-unit development, with standards that emphasize compatibility with surrounding neighborhoods while allowing for efficient use of land. They follow a streamlined review process and are eligible for various development alternatives and special district applications, making them an important component of Bend's housing diversity strategy.

What it is: A quadplex is a residential building containing four dwelling units on one lot or parcel. While the code doesn't provide a specific definition of "quadplex" in the definitions section, it's consistently referenced throughout as part of the "duplex, triplex and quadplex development" category, indicating it's a four-unit residential building.

Design Standards Summary

Building Separation Standards

Detached dwelling units must be a minimum of six feet apart as measured between their building footprints 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This applies when the quadplex consists of separate buildings rather than attached units.

Access and Driveway Standards

Alley Access Priority: For lots or parcels abutting an alley, access must be taken from the alley in accordance with BDC 3.1.400(F)(3) 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Street Access Standards: When there's no alley, quadplexes may have four driveway approaches 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code and must comply with the following:

  • The total width of all driveway approaches must not exceed 32 feet per frontage 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Driveway approaches may be separated when located on a local street. If approaches are separated, they must be separated by a minimum of seven feet 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code

Multiple Frontage Standards: In addition, lots or parcels with more than one frontage must comply with the following: Lots or parcels must access the street with the lowest classification. Lots or parcels with frontages only on collectors and/or arterial streets may have one driveway approach 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code.

Specific Access Configurations: For lots with frontages only on local streets: Quadplexes may have four driveway approaches not exceeding 32 feet in total width on one frontage or two driveway approaches not exceeding 32 feet in total width on one frontage and one maximum 16-foot-wide driveway approach on one other frontage 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Additional configuration: Quadplexes may have four driveway approaches not exceeding 32 feet in total width on one frontage or two driveway approaches not exceeding 32 feet in total width on one frontage and one maximum 16-foot-wide driveway approach on one other frontage 2.7.4150 Residential Zoning Districts | Bend Development Code.

Clear Vision Requirements

Clear vision standards do not apply between driveway approaches for duplexes, triplexes and quadplexes on local streets. All other standards in BDC 3.1.500, Clear Vision Areas, apply 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Minimum Driveway Width

The minimum driveway width must be 10 feet 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Architectural Design Standards

Specific Quadplex Standards Apply: This section's architectural design standards apply to all of the following types of buildings: Triplex. Quadplex. Townhome. Single-room occupancy with six or fewer units 2.1.950 Design Standards (Triplex, Quadplex, Townhome, and Single-Room Occupancy) | Bend Development Code. These standards include:

Garage Door Standards: The maximum combined garage door width facing the street is 50 percent of the total building width. The maximum combined garage door width facing the street may be up to 60 percent of the total building width if the front door entrance is within 10 feet of the longest street-facing wall of the dwelling unit 2.1.950 Design Standards (Triplex, Quadplex, Townhome, and Single-Room Occupancy) | Bend Development Code.

Window and Door Requirements: A minimum of 15 percent of the area of all street facing facades must include windows and/or doors 2.1.950 Design Standards (Triplex, Quadplex, Townhome, and Single-Room Occupancy) | Bend Development Code.

Multi-Unit Standards Also Apply: This section applies to all of the following types of buildings: Multi-unit residential 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code, which includes quadplexes. These standards require:

  • All building elevations must provide doors, porches, balconies, terraces and/or windows for a minimum of 30 percent of each full and partial building story. A minimum of 40 percent is required for street-facing elevations located within 50 feet of a front lot line 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code
  • A minimum of one building must have an entrance facing the street or be oriented to a side yard when a direct pedestrian walkway is provided between the building entrance and the street 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code

Front Door Orientation Standards

For duplexes, triplexes and quadplexes, this standard is only required to be met for one of the dwelling units 2.1.1100 Other Design Standards | Bend Development Code (referring to front door orientation requirements).

Review Process

Quadplexes are included in Minimum Development Standards Review for Single-Unit Detached Dwellings, Townhomes, Accessory Dwelling Units, Duplexes, Triplexes, Quadplexes, Single Room Occupancies with Six or Fewer Units and Cottage Cluster Developments 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code.

Pedestrian Access Requirements

A hard surface pedestrian access route, a minimum width of four feet, must be provided from each dwelling unit to the street upon which it is addressed. If the route is fenced, there must be a gate to allow access 4.2.400 Minimum Development Standards Review | Bend Development Code.

Conversion Allowances

Conversion of an existing single-unit detached dwelling or duplex to a triplex or quadplex is allowed; provided, that the conversion does not increase nonconformance 2.1.200 Permitted and Conditional Uses | Bend Development Code.

Special Vehicle Access Features

Ribbon Driveways: Ribbon driveways may be used to provide access to single-unit detached dwellings, accessory dwelling units, townhomes, duplexes, triplexes and quadplexes 3.1.400 Vehicular Access Management | Bend Development Code with specific design requirements.

Backing Operations: Backing from an access onto a public street is not permitted except for single-unit, duplex, triplex or quadplex dwellings backing onto a local street 3.1.400 Vehicular Access Management | Bend Development Code.

Special Context Applications

Urban Dwelling Sites: Accessory dwelling units, townhomes, duplexes, triplexes, quadplexes and multi-unit 3.8.800 Urban Dwelling Sites | Bend Development Code are permitted in Urban Dwelling Sites with special design standards that replace the design standards of the underlying zoning district and all the standards in BDC 3.6.200(D), Townhomes, 3.6.200(H), Duplex, Triplex and Quadplex Development 3.8.800 Urban Dwelling Sites | Bend Development Code.

Master Plan Integration

Several master planned developments specifically mention quadplexes:

  • The Stevens Ranch Master Planned Development implements the BCP residential density policy for DSL/Stevens Ranch by ensuring the capacity for at least 1,000 dwelling units within the Master Plan boundary, including at least 11 percent single-unit attached housing and at least 41 percent multi-unit and duplex/triplex/quadplex housing types 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code
  • Based on the planned zoning, the Easton Master Plan must ensure capacity for a minimum of 720 housing units, including at least 244 units of townhomes, duplexes, triplexes, quadplexes and/or multi-unit 2.7.4150 Residential Zoning Districts | Bend Development Code
  • Based on the zoning implementing the required land use designations in the Southwest Expansion Area, the Ponderosa Master Plan must ensure capacity for a minimum of 251 housing units, including a minimum of 39 townhomes and 146 multi-unit, duplex, triplex, and/or quadplex units 2.7.5040 Residential Zoning Districts | Bend Development Code

Alley Access Requirements in Some Areas

For lots or parcels abutting an alley, access may be required to be taken from the alley in accordance with BDC 3.1.400(F)(3) 2.7.4250 Residential | Bend Development Code in certain master planned areas.

Triplexes and quadplexes 3.1.400 Vehicular Access Management | Bend Development Code have special considerations regarding alley access requirements in certain contexts.

Summary

Quadplexes in Bend are four-unit residential developments that can be configured as attached or detached units on a single lot. The design standards focus on managing vehicular access through controlled driveway approaches (up to four), ensuring adequate building separation when detached, maintaining pedestrian connectivity, and providing architectural detail including specific garage door width limitations and window/door area requirements. Quadplexes are treated as a middle-density housing type that represents the upper end of small-scale multi-unit development, with standards that emphasize compatibility with surrounding neighborhoods while maximizing efficient use of land. They follow a streamlined review process, are eligible for various development alternatives and special district applications, and play a significant role in Bend's housing diversity strategy as evidenced by their inclusion in multiple master planned developments throughout the city.

The code addresses Residential care homes and facilities shall comply with the following standards 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code, with a key distinction being that Site Plan Review shall be required for new structures to be used as residential care facilities, to ensure compliance with the licensing, parking, and other requirements of this code. Residential care homes are exempt from this requirement 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

This suggests that "residential care homes" (which would typically include those with 5 or fewer residents) are smaller-scale operations that are exempt from the more intensive Site Plan Review process, while "residential care facilities" (larger operations) require full Site Plan Review.

Design Standards Summary

Licensing Requirements

All residential care homes and facilities shall be duly licensed by the State of Oregon 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This is the primary regulatory requirement that applies to all residential care operations regardless of size.

Review Process

Streamlined Process for Residential Care Homes: Residential care homes are exempt from this requirement 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code (referring to Site Plan Review). This means residential care homes, which would include those with 5 or fewer residents, follow a simpler approval process and don't require the comprehensive Site Plan Review that larger residential care facilities must undergo.

Underlying Zoning Standards

Since residential care homes are exempt from specific design review requirements, they must comply with the standard requirements of whatever residential zone they're located in, including:

  • Standard setback requirements for the applicable zone
  • Building height limits for the zone
  • Lot coverage maximums
  • Parking requirements of the underlying zone
  • All other applicable zoning district standards

Integration with Neighborhood Character

The exemption from Site Plan Review suggests that residential care homes with 5 or fewer residents are intended to operate more like typical residential uses, maintaining neighborhood compatibility without requiring special design accommodations.

The emphasis on State of Oregon licensing indicates that the primary regulatory oversight for residential care homes comes from state-level health and safety requirements rather than local design standards. The local code defers to state expertise in determining appropriate operational standards for these facilities.

Residential care homes appear to be permitted uses in residential districts, meaning they can operate by right (subject to licensing) without requiring special permits or conditional use approval, further emphasizing their compatibility with residential neighborhoods.

Summary

Residential care homes with 5 or fewer residents in Bend are regulated primarily through state licensing requirements rather than local design standards. This approach recognizes that smaller residential care homes are more compatible with neighborhood character and can operate effectively within standard residential development patterns. The key design principle is maintaining residential character while ensuring compliance with state health and safety standards through the licensing process.

The distinction between "residential care homes" and "residential care facilities" appears to be based on scale and intensity of use, with homes being smaller operations (likely 5 or fewer residents) that integrate well into residential neighborhoods, while facilities are larger operations requiring more comprehensive design review.

posts.html:
What is an Adult Day Care?

Adult day care facility is defined as "community-based group programs designed to meet the needs of adults with functional and cognitive impairments through individual plans of care that are structured, comprehensive and provide a variety of health, social and related support services in protective settings during part of the day but provide less than 24-hour care." D Definitions | Bend Development Code

Where Adult Day Care is Permitted

According to Table 2.1.200 in the Bend Development Code, adult day care facilities are permitted (P) in all residential zoning districts: RL (Low Density Residential), RS (Standard Density Residential), RM-10 (Medium-10 Density Residential), RM (Medium Density Residential), RH (High Density Residential), and UAR (Urban Area Reserve) 2.1.200 Permitted and Conditional Uses | Bend Development Code.

Design Standards Summary

Adult day care facilities in Bend must comply with several design standards:

1. Architectural Design Standards Adult day care facilities are subject to special standards as described in BDC 2.1.900, Architectural Design Standards, and/or BDC Chapter 3.6, Special Standards and Regulations for Certain Uses 2.1.200 Permitted and Conditional Uses | Bend Development Code. These standards apply to "all other types of permitted/conditional nonresidential use buildings listed in Table 2.1.200 when built in a Residential Zone" 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code.

2. Building Orientation Requirements At least one building must have an entrance facing the street or be oriented to a side yard when a direct pedestrian walkway is provided between the building entrance and the street, with at least one entrance provided not more than 30 feet from the closest sidewalk or street 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code.

3. Detailed Design Requirements All buildings must provide detailed design along all elevations which are visible from the street(s) adjacent to the property. This can be achieved through either a "Menu Option" (using at least six of 12 specified architectural features) or a "Design Review Option" (requiring Type II application and review) 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code.

4. Zone-Specific Standards The facility must comply with the underlying residential zone standards for setbacks, lot coverage, building height, and other dimensional requirements as specified in the respective zoning district.

5. Special Use Standards As a nonresidential use in a residential district, adult day care facilities must meet compatibility standards to ensure they blend appropriately with the surrounding residential character.

The design standards are intended to ensure that adult day care facilities maintain the residential character of neighborhoods while providing necessary community services for adults with functional and cognitive impairments.

What is a Residential Care Facility (6 or More Residents)

While I couldn't locate a specific definition for "residential care facility" in the Bend Development Code definitions, the code does define "Nursing/convalescent homes" with a note that says "(also see 'Residential care facility')" and defines it as "a residence, institution, or place other than a hospital or assisted living facility that operates and maintains facilities providing 24-hour convalescent or chronic care, or both, for two or more ill or infirm patients not related to the nursing home administrator or owner by blood or marriage" N Definitions | Bend Development Code.

Where Residential Care Facilities (6 or More Residents) are Permitted

According to Table 2.1.200 in the Bend Development Code, residential care facilities with 6 or more residents are:

  • Not permitted (N) in RL (Low Density Residential) and RS (Standard Density Residential) zones
  • Conditionally permitted (C) in RM-10 (Medium-10 Density Residential) zone
  • Permitted (P) in RM (Medium Density Residential) and RH (High Density Residential) zones
  • Not permitted (N) in UAR (Urban Area Reserve) zone 2.1.200 Permitted and Conditional Uses | Bend Development Code

Design Standards Summary

Residential care facilities with 6 or more residents must comply with several requirements:

Site Plan Review Requirement Site Plan Review is required for new structures to be used as residential care facilities, to ensure compliance with the licensing, parking, and other requirements of this code 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. 4. Conditional Use Requirements In zones where they require conditional use permits (RM-10), these facilities must meet the conditional use permit criteria and standards outlined in BDC Chapter 4.4.

The distinction between residential care "homes" (5 or fewer residents) and "facilities" (6 or more residents) appears to be primarily based on the number of residents served, with facilities requiring more rigorous review processes and being limited to higher-density residential zones.

What it is: A family childcare home caring for 16 or fewer children is classified as a home business under Bend's Development Code. Based on the home business provisions in BDC 3.6.200(N), family childcare homes would fall under either Class B or Class C home business categories depending on their scale and operations 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Design Standards Summary

Fencing Requirements

Fences located in the front setback must not exceed four feet in height for child care facilities and registered or certified family child care homes 3.2.500 Fences and Retaining Walls | Bend Development Code. In side and rear setbacks, fences may be up to six feet in height.

Home Business Standards

As a home business, family childcare homes must comply with these design standards:

General Requirements:

  • The home business must be conducted wholly within lawfully built, enclosed structures and in such a manner as not to give an outward appearance of a business 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • The home business must not result in any alterations or additions to a structure that will change the primary use or the primary use's Building Code classification 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • The primary use of the dwelling unit must remain residential 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Outdoor Storage:

  • Outdoor storage, including but not limited to inventory, supplies, or equipment, must be completely screened behind a sight-obscuring wall or fence or within an enclosed structure so that the products, equipment or materials are not visible from the public right-of-way or abutting properties or common areas 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Parking:

  • A maximum of two personal motor vehicles and/or trailers owned or leased by the residents and used in conjunction with a home business may be parked outdoors 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Any additional motor vehicles and/or trailers utilized for a home business must be parked inside a lawfully built, enclosed structure 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Signage:

  • One nonilluminated wall or window sign limited to two square feet in area and located on or below the first story at a maximum height of 14 feet is permitted 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Operating Hours and Clients: For Class B home businesses: Clients or customers are only permitted at the home business from 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. Monday through Friday and 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Saturday and Sunday 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

The specific approval process would depend on whether the family childcare home qualifies as a Class B (Type I permit required) or Class C (Type II permit required) home business based on the number of non-resident employees and scope of operations.

What it is: Multi-unit residential developments with more than 4 units fall under specific regulations in Bend's Development Code, particularly for developments of "five units or more" in the Medium Density Residential (RM) and High Density Residential (RH) Districts 2.1.1000 Multi-Unit Residential Districts (RM, RH) | Bend Development Code. These districts are intended to provide land for a mix of middle housing, multi-unit dwellings and single-room occupancies in locations that are convenient to service commercial uses and future transit opportunities 2.1.1000 Multi-Unit Residential Districts (RM, RH) | Bend Development Code.

Design Standards Summary

Architectural Design Standards

Multi-unit residential buildings are subject to BDC 2.1.900, Architectural Design Standards, which are intended to provide detailed, human-scale design, while affording flexibility to use a variety of building styles 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code.

Building Form and Orientation:

  • All building elevations must provide doors, porches, balconies, terraces and/or windows for a minimum of 30 percent of each full and partial building story. A minimum of 40 percent is required for street-facing elevations located within 50 feet of a front lot line 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code
  • A minimum of one building must have an entrance facing the street or be oriented to a side yard when a direct pedestrian walkway is provided between the building entrance and the street 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code

Detailed Design Requirements: Multi-unit buildings must provide detailed design through either:

  • Menu Option (Type I): Using at least six of 12 specified architectural features on all applicable elevations 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code, or
  • Design Review Option (Type II): Showing that the general size, shape, and scale of the structure(s) are architecturally compatible with the site and surrounding neighborhood 2.1.900 Architectural Design Standards | Bend Development Code

Setback Standards

When multi-unit buildings containing five or more units abut a detached single-unit dwelling or duplex on land designated RS, any side or rear setback abutting the RS land must increase one-half foot for each foot by which the building height exceeds 20 feet 2.7.4150 Residential Zoning Districts | Bend Development Code.

Common Open Space Requirements (20+ Units)

A minimum of 10 percent of the site area must be designated and permanently reserved as usable common open space in all multiple-unit developments with 20 units or more 2.1.1000 Multi-Unit Residential Districts (RM, RH) | Bend Development Code. However, a common open space credit of 50 percent may be granted when the development is located within one-quarter mile walking distance of a public park with a direct, accessible, and maintained trail or sidewalk that does not cross an arterial or collector street 2.1.1000 Multi-Unit Residential Districts (RM, RH) | Bend Development Code.

Private Open Space Requirements

Ground-floor units must have patios or decks at least four feet deep and measuring at least 48 square feet. A minimum of 50 percent of all upper-floor units must have balconies or porches at least four feet deep and measuring at least 48 square feet 2.1.1000 Multi-Unit Residential Districts (RM, RH) | Bend Development Code.

Trash Receptacle Standards

Trash receptacles must not be located within setbacks for property lines shared with single-unit detached and attached dwellings and must be screened on at least three sides with an evergreen hedge or solid fence or wall of not less than six feet in height 2.1.1000 Multi-Unit Residential Districts (RM, RH) | Bend Development Code.

Housing Mix Requirements (RM District)

At least 50 percent of the total housing units in residential developments on any property or combination of properties between three acres and 20 acres in the RM District must be middle housing, single-room occupancy and/or multi-unit dwellings 2.1.1000 Multi-Unit Residential Districts (RM, RH) | Bend Development Code.

Height Standards

Multi-unit buildings may be up to 45 feet in height in the RM District and up to 55 feet in the RH District, depending on the specific zoning district and overlay zones that may apply.
