What they are: Micro-unit developments are permitted in the RM-10, RM, RH, MU and MN Zoning Districts and in the Bend Central District. Micro-unit developments are also permitted as part of a mixed-use development in the Commercial and Mixed-Use Zoning Districts or as part of a neighborhood commercial site in the RS, RM and RH District 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code. Four micro-units equal one dwelling unit for density calculation purposes 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code.

Design Standards Summary

Unit Size Requirements

  • Minimum Floor Area: 150 square feet 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code
  • Maximum Floor Area: 400 square feet, exclusive of lofts 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code
  • Exception: Accessible units designed to meet the accessible requirements of the current Oregon Building Code may be 450 square feet, exclusive of lofts 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code

Private Facilities Required in Each Unit

Each micro-unit must contain an area that includes: an under-the-counter refrigerator with a dedicated outlet; contiguous countertop work area of not less than four square feet; and twenty-amp small appliance branch circuit located above the countertop work area 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code.

Each unit must also have a bathroom that contains a toilet and a shower and/or bathtub, and a sink. For the purposes of a micro-unit, the sink may be larger than 18 inches by 18 inches and will not be considered a kitchen 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code.

Restrictions: A kitchen is not allowed, except the sink required may be larger than 18 inches by 18 inches 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code.

Common Facilities Requirements

  • One common kitchen must be provided for every 10 micro-units or portion thereof. A common kitchen must include a sink larger than 18 inches by 18 inches, a refrigerator, and a stove, range top, or oven and be a minimum of 120 square feet in area 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code
  • One common laundry facility must be provided for every 10 micro-units or portion thereof 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code

Private and Common Space Requirements

In RS, RM and RH zones: minimum 10 square feet of private space or 20 square feet of common space per micro-unit 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code. Private space must be provided with a minimum dimension of five feet on any side and common space must be provided with a minimum dimension of 10 feet on any side 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code.

Garage and Orientation Standards

  • The maximum combined garage door width facing the street is 50 percent of the total building width 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code
  • At least one front door entrance of the micro-unit development must orientate to an abutting street or open to a porch covered by either a roof or enclosed floor area 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code

Parking Standards

  • There are no minimum parking requirements 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code
  • The maximum is one and one-half parking spaces per micro-unit 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code
  • Parking is prohibited between the street and the micro-unit development when more than three parking spaces are provided 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code

Additional Requirements

  • Micro-unit developments require a minimum percentage landscape coverage of 15 percent of the gross lot area 3.2.300 New Landscaping | Bend Development Code
  • Trash receptacles must be screened on at least three sides with an evergreen hedge or solid fence or wall of not less than six feet in height 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code
  • The use of a micro-unit as a short-term rental is prohibited 3.8.200 Micro-Unit Development | Bend Development Code

All home businesses must meet the following operational standards: the home businesses must be owned and/or operated by a resident of the home business site; the primary use of the dwelling unit must remain residential; the home business, except for outdoor storage, must be conducted wholly within lawfully built, enclosed structures and in such a manner as not to give an outward appearance of a business 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Additional General Requirements:

  • Outdoor storage, including but not limited to inventory, supplies, or equipment, must be completely screened behind a sight-obscuring wall or fence or within an enclosed structure so that the products, equipment or materials are not visible from the public right-of-way or abutting properties or common areas 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • A maximum of two personal motor vehicles and/or trailers owned or leased by the residents and used in conjunction with a home business may be parked outdoors 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • One nonilluminated wall or window sign limited to two square feet in area and located on or below the first story at a maximum height of 14 feet is permitted 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • The home business must not produce radio or TV interference, glare, dust, vibration, smoke or odor beyond allowable levels 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Class A Home Business

A Class A home business is one where the residents use their home as a place of work and no nonresident employees nor clients/customers come to the site. Class A home businesses also provide an opportunity for the residents to use their home as a business address but not as a place of work, for professions where the work is performed online or done at other locations 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Review Process: Class A home businesses are considered permitted accessory uses. No land use approval is required 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Standards:

  • Only the residents of the dwelling unit participate in the home business on site 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • No nonresident employees nor clients/customers come to the home business site 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

  • No more than 25 percent of the dwelling unit, including the floor area of garages, accessory structures and an ADU, may be utilized for all home business uses 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Class B Home Business

A Class B home business is one where the residents use their home as a place of work and involves a limited number of nonresident employees and/or clients or customers coming to the site 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Review Process: A Class B home business is subject to the Type I procedures outlined in BDC Chapter 4.1, Development Review and Procedures 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Standards:

  • Clients or customers are only permitted at the home business from 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. Monday through Friday and 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Saturday and Sunday 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • No more than 25 percent of the dwelling unit, including the floor area of garages, accessory structures and an ADU, may be utilized for all home business uses 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • A Class B home business is not permitted on a site with a Type II short-term rental 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Standards:

  • Only the residents of the home and up to three nonresident employees can participate in the home business. Off-site employees are permitted 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Clients or customers are only permitted at the home business from 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. Monday through Friday and 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Saturday and Sunday 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • A Class C home business is not permitted on a site with a Type II short-term rental 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Prohibited Uses

Prohibited uses include: any business utilizing the residence as a headquarters or dispatch centers where employees come to the site and are dispatched to other locations; on-site retail sales (except incidental items); ambulance service; animal hospital, veterinary services, kennels or daytime or overnight animal boarding; any business involving repair, reconditioning, after-market modification or customization, sales or storage of motorized vehicles, boats, recreational vehicles, airplanes, or large equipment on site; and marijuana businesses 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

posts.html:
What they are: Accessory uses and structures are those of a nature customarily incidental and subordinate to the primary use or structure on the same lot. Typical accessory structures include detached garages, sheds, workshops, greenhouses and similar structures 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. Note that this section does not apply to accessory dwelling units (ADUs) 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code, which have their own separate regulations.

Design Standards Summary

Primary Use Requirement

An accessory structure or use may only be permitted on a lot or parcel after the primary use is established. The accessory use must be a permitted use in the zoning district 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Facility Restrictions

A half bathroom and/or a wet bar may not be installed within an accessory structure unless the property owner signs a City of Bend compliance form stating that the structure will not be used as a dwelling unit 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Prohibited Features:

  • A kitchen is not allowed 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • A full bathroom is not allowed 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Size and Height Standards

  • Floor Area: The maximum floor area of an accessory structure in a residential zoning district must not exceed 1,500 square feet 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  • Building Height: The building height of a detached accessory structure must not exceed 25 feet 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code

Attachment Standards

In order to consider the accessory structure to be attached to the primary dwelling unit, it must be attached by one of the following options and there must be an opening that allows for internal access through livable space to the primary portion of the dwelling unit: the accessory structure must share a common wall for at least 25 percent of the length of the primary dwelling unit; or the entire length of one elevation of the accessory structure must be attached to the primary dwelling unit 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

The shared or attached wall must be the wall of an enclosed interior space, and does not include porches, patios, decks or stoops 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code.

Special Provisions for Specific Developments

Cottage Cluster Developments: Accessory structures must not exceed 400 square feet in floor area 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code, with an exception for garages.

Wildflower Master Planned Development (Special Standards): There is no limit to the number of accessory uses and structures on a lot or parcel. There is no maximum square footage of individual accessory structures. Full bathrooms are allowed in fitness center/gym buildings, clubhouses, and pool houses/pool maintenance buildings. Kitchens and outdoor cooking areas are allowed as part of a community center/clubhouse or leasing/property management building. Half bathrooms are permitted in buildings associated with property maintenance, such as garages, storage buildings, workshops, or similar buildings 2.7.3145 Special Development Standards | Bend Development Code.

Setback Requirements

In various districts, specific setback requirements apply. For example, accessory structures, garages or carports must be set back a minimum of 20 feet from property lines fronting a public street Bend CodeBend Code in certain developments.

Uses in Mixed-Use Districts

The setback standards apply to all new buildings and any building expansion, including primary structures and accessory structures 2.3.300 Development Standards | Bend Development Code in Mixed-Use Districts.

The standards ensure that accessory structures remain subordinate to the primary use while providing flexibility for property owners to add functional structures that complement their main dwelling.

There is no maximum square footage of individual accessory structures. Full bathrooms are allowed in fitness center/gym buildings, clubhouses, and pool houses/pool maintenance buildings. Kitchens and outdoor cooking areas are allowed as part of a community center/clubhouse or leasing/property management building. Half bathrooms are permitted in buildings associated with property maintenance, such as garages, storage buildings, workshops, or similar buildings 2.7.3145 Special Development Standards | Bend Development Code.


Setback Requirements

In various districts, specific setback requirements apply. For example, accessory structures, garages or carports must be set back a minimum of 20 feet from property lines fronting a public street Bend CodeBend Code in certain developments.


Uses in Mixed-Use Districts

The setback standards apply to all new buildings and any building expansion, including primary structures and accessory structures 2.3.300 Development Standards | Bend Development Code in Mixed-Use Districts.

The standards ensure that accessory structures remain subordinate to the primary use while providing flexibility for property owners to add functional structures that complement their main dwelling.

What it is: The purpose of cottage housing development is to: provide a housing type that responds to differing household sizes and ages (e.g., retirees, small families, single-person households), and offers opportunities for affordability; provide opportunities for small, single-unit dwellings in several residential zoning districts by creating special land division and on-site development regulations that allow this type of use; encourage creation of usable open space for residents of the development through flexibility in density and development standards 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code.

Where allowed: Cottage housing developments are allowed in the following districts: Standard Density Residential (RS), Medium Density Residential (RM) and Medium-10 Residential (RM-10) 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code.

Design Standards Summary

Development Size and Layout

  • Cottage housing developments must contain a minimum of four and a maximum of 12 cottages arranged in a cluster. A cottage housing development may contain more than one cluster 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • There is no maximum lot coverage for cottage housing developments 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • There is no minimum lot size for cottage housing developments 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Unit Size Requirements

  • The maximum floor area per dwelling unit is 1,200 square feet. Garages are not included in the calculation of the total floor area 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Setback and Separation Standards

Because CHDs are a unique type of development, setbacks are measured differently than for a traditional development. The exterior boundary of the CHD development area is considered to be the edge of the development area for the purposes of calculating perimeter setbacks from surrounding properties 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code.

Perimeter Setbacks:

  • The minimum front setback is 10 feet 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • The minimum setback from all other exterior boundary property lines is five feet 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Interior Building Separation:

  • There must be a minimum separation of six feet between the building footprints of the cottages. On cottage sides with a main entrance, the minimum separation is 10 feet 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • Garages and carports accessed from a street must be set back a minimum of 20 feet 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Common Open Space Requirements

Common open space is intended to be an amenity shared by all residents of the cottage housing development 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code:

  • Provide a centrally located open space area for the cottage housing development and have cottages abutting at least two sides 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • Contain a minimum of 400 square feet per cottage 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • At least 50 percent of the cottages must abut a common open space 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • Each cottage must be connected to the common open space by a pedestrian pathway 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • Common open space must have a minimum average width of 20 feet 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Private Open Space Requirements

Provide a total of 400 square feet of private open space that includes a minimum of 200 square feet of contiguous usable open space adjacent to each cottage with no dimension less than 10 feet 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code.

Cottage Orientation and Features

  • At least 50 percent of the cottages must be oriented around and have their main entrance facing the common open space 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • Each cottage must include a covered entry and/or an uncovered patio or deck 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Entry/Patio Requirements:

  • A covered entry of at least 80 square feet with a minimum dimension of six feet on any side; or an uncovered patio or deck of at least 80 square feet with a minimum dimension of six feet on any side 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Garage and Accessory Structure Standards

  • Individual detached garages cannot exceed 450 square feet of floor area and no more than 18 feet in height. Only one garage is allowed per cottage 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • Accessory dwelling units are not permitted in cottage housing developments (CHDs) 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • Accessory structures for common usage are allowed in the common open space areas. Other accessory structures (except garages) are prohibited 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Parking Standards

  • There are no minimum or maximum parking requirements 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • Parking must not be located in the perimeter setbacks and must be screened from streets and adjacent residential uses by a landscape buffer 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • All parking must provide a minimum of 24 feet for maneuvering and backing movements from garages, carports and/or parking areas 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Density Requirements

Minimum Density:

  • RS and RM-10 Districts: four dwelling units per gross acre 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code
  • RM District: 12 dwelling units per gross acre 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Density Calculation: Dwelling units 600 square feet or smaller: 0.25 of a dwelling unit. Dwelling units 601 to 1,200 square feet: 0.50 of a dwelling unit 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code

Administrative Requirements

The CC&Rs must create a homeowners' association that will provide for maintenance of all common areas in the cottage housing development 3.8.500 Cottage Housing Development | Bend Development Code.

What it is: Cottage cluster development is a distinct housing type that's separate from cottage housing development. Cottage cluster developments are allowed in the following districts: Low Density Residential (RL) District, Standard Density Residential (RS), Medium Density Residential (RM) and Medium-10 Residential (RM-10) 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code.

Approval Process: Cottage cluster developments are subject to BDC 4.2.400, Minimum Development Standards Review. The procedures and criteria of BDC Chapter 4.3 apply to cottage cluster development subdivisions 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code.

Design Standards Summary

Development Size Requirements

  • Cottage cluster developments must contain a minimum of three cottages 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code
  • There is no maximum lot coverage or floor area ratio for cottage cluster developments 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code

Cottage Unit Size and Building Standards

  • The maximum cottage building footprint must be less than 900 square feet. It does not include detached garages or carports; accessory structures; or unenclosed covered or uncovered porches, patios, decks, balconies or stoops 18 inches or less 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code
  • Individual attached garages up to 200 square feet are exempt from the calculation of maximum building footprint for cottages 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code

Setbacks and Building Separation

Because cottage clusters are a unique type of development, setbacks are measured differently than for a traditional development. The exterior boundary of the cottage cluster development site is considered to be the edge of the development site for the purposes of calculating perimeter setbacks from surrounding properties 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code.

Building Separation:

  • There must be a minimum separation of six feet between the building footprints of the cottages. On cottage sides with a main entrance, the minimum separation is six feet. Structures other than cottages must meet minimum building code setback requirements 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code
  • Garages and carports accessed from a street must be set back a minimum of 20 feet 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code

Common Courtyard Requirements

A minimum of 65 percent of the cottages within a cottage cluster development must share a common courtyard in order to provide a sense of openness and community of residents 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code.

Common Courtyard Design Standards:

  • A cottage cluster development must contain a minimum of three and a maximum of 12 cottages per common courtyard 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code
  • The common courtyard must be a single, contiguous piece and separated from another common courtyard by a minimum of 10 feet 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code
  • Cottages must abut the common courtyard on at least two sides of the courtyard 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code
  • The common courtyard must contain a minimum of 150 square feet per cottage within the associated cluster 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code
  • The common courtyard must be a minimum of 15 feet wide at its narrowest dimension 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code
  • The common courtyard must be developed with a mix of landscaping, lawn area, pedestrian paths, and/or paved courtyard area, and may also include recreational amenities 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code

Cottage Orientation Standards

Each cottage within a cluster must either abut the common courtyard or must be directly connected to it by a pedestrian path. A minimum of 50 percent of cottages within a cluster must be oriented to the common courtyard and must: have a front door entrance facing the common courtyard or have a front door entrance open to a covered porch that has an entry facing the common courtyard; be within 10 feet from the common courtyard, measured from an exterior wall of the cottage or covered porch to the nearest edge of the common courtyard 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code.

Community Buildings

Cottage cluster developments may include community buildings for the shared use of residents that provide space for accessory uses such as community meeting rooms, guest housing, exercise rooms, day care, or community eating areas 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code.

Community Building Standards:

  • Each cottage cluster is permitted one community building 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code
  • A community building that meets the BDC definition of a dwelling unit must have a building footprint less than 900 square feet, unless a covenant is recorded against the property stating that the structure is not a legal dwelling unit and will not be used as a primary dwelling 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code

Accessory Structures

Accessory structures must not exceed 400 square feet in floor area 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code, with an exception for garages.

Parking Standards

Off-street parking may be arranged in clusters 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code, subject to specific clustering standards.

Restrictions

  • Accessory dwelling units are not permitted in cottage cluster developments 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code

Administrative Requirements

The CC&Rs must create a homeowners' association that will provide for maintenance of all common areas in the cottage housing development 3.8.900 Cottage Cluster Developments | Bend Development Code.

The key distinction from cottage housing development is that cottage cluster development emphasizes the common courtyard design and requires a higher percentage of cottages to share this central space, creating a more tightly clustered community arrangement.

posts.html:
What It Is

Based on Bend's Development Code, residential care homes and facilities are required to be duly licensed by the State of Oregon 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code and are designed to provide care and supervision for residents who need assistance with daily living activities.

The code distinguishes between residential care homes and residential care facilities, with residential care homes being exempt from site plan review requirements, while site plan review is required for new structures to be used as residential care facilities, to ensure compliance with the licensing, parking, and other requirements of this code 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code. This suggests that residential care facilities are larger operations (like those with 6 or more units) that require more stringent review processes.

The code also references nursing/convalescent homes, which are defined as "a residence, institution, or place other than a hospital or assisted living facility that operates and maintains facilities providing 24-hour convalescent or chronic care, or both, for two or more ill or infirm patients not related to the nursing home administrator or owner by blood or marriage" N Definitions | Bend Development Code and notes that readers should also see "Residential care facility" for related information.

Design Standards Summary

Regulatory Requirements:

  1. State Licensing: All residential care homes and facilities must be duly licensed by the State of Oregon 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code
  2. Site Plan Review: Site Plan Review is required for new structures to be used as residential care facilities 3.6.200 Residential Uses | Bend Development Code (facilities with 6+ units would fall into this category)

Zoning Exemptions:

  • Residential care homes/facilities are exempt from residential density standards 2.1.600 Residential Density | Bend Development Code that apply to other residential developments in all residential districts

Development Standards: The code requires that residential care facilities comply with licensing, parking, and other requirements, but the specific design standards would be determined through the Site Plan Review process, which ensures compliance with:

  • State licensing requirements
  • Parking standards (per BDC Chapter 3.3)
  • Building and safety codes
  • Other applicable municipal requirements

Review Process: Residential care facilities require Site Plan Review, which is a more comprehensive review process than what smaller residential care homes require, ensuring that larger facilities properly integrate with their neighborhoods and meet all safety and operational requirements.

The distinction between residential care homes (which are exempt from site plan review) and residential care facilities (which require site plan review) suggests that facilities with 6 or more units fall into the "facility" category requiring the more rigorous review process.
